verses.roman:
manorathān karoty uccair
jano daiva-hatān api
yujyate harṣa-śokābhyāṁ
tathāpy ājñāṁ karomi te

synonyms: manaḥ-rathān—his desires; karoti—carries out; uccaiḥ—fervently; daiva—by Providence; hatān—thwarted; yujyate—he is confronted; harṣa-śokābhyām—by happiness and distress; tathā api—nonetheless; ājñām—order; karomi—I will do; te—your.
translation: An ordinary person is determined lo act on his desires even when fate prevents their fulfillment. Therefore he encounters both happiness and distress. Yet even though such is the case, I will execute your order.

purport.content: Śrīla Viśvanātha Cakravartī explains that although what Akrūra said was courteous and encouraging, his hidden meaning was far different. What he really meant was this: "Your plan is not fit to execute, yet I will carry it out since you are the King and I am your subject, and in any case, you are about to die."
